Important information about the flu from Ontario County Public Health:

This flu season, 89,597 New Yorkers have tested positive for flu. There are 3 main message points about flu:

1. Get your flu shot (The flu shot is not a magic cloak that prevents the flu. The flu shot helps your body build memory cells to fight against the flu if you are exposed. Flu shots can be lifesaving.)
2. Stop the spread (This is done by washing your hands frequently, cover your cough with your elbow, avoid touching your eyes, mouth, and nose and stay home if you are sick.)
3. Take antiviral medication if prescribed. (If you have a sudden onset of fever and body aches call your healthcare provider quickly. If you are prescribed antivirals take them as instructed.)

1991: Construction of Canandaigua Academy- East Street

"The culminating event was the Grand March. On a beautiful, sunny, crisp October day, 70 classes, from the Class of 1916 to the Class of 2004, gathered at the 1907 Academy on Main Street. Former Academy principals Alton Farnsworth and John Smigler shared their recollections with the assembled crowd. The procession, including horse and carraige, vinatge cars with class members, homecoming floats, students and banners, made its way to the Middle School. Framed by the auditorium, former Academy principal John Wilcox added his recollections. The final leg of the march brought all the participants to the new high school, the fourth building to bear the name Canandaigua Academy. Superintedent Stephen Uebbing, Principal Chet Starowiz and Board President Jayne Bobsein accepted the keys to the school. Speeches, ribbon cutting, tours and many reunions took place. It was a happy day in Canandaigua."

Source: 200 years of Learning
1791-1991- Canandaigua Schools

Published: August 1992
